entity1.name: Cooking
entity1.description: The process of preparing food by applying heat or other methods to transform raw ingredients into edible dishes.;;;A food preservation method that involves storing food in a brine solution to prevent the growth of microorganisms that cause spoilage.;;;A process where substances are transformed into different substances through chemical changes.;;;A mixture of two or more immiscible substances, such as oil and water, where one substance is dispersed throughout the other in very small droplets.;;;A process in chemistry where two immiscible substances, such as oil and water, are combined to form a stable mixture.;;;Processes in which one or more substances are transformed into different substances, playing a key role in the cooking process.;;;The process of preparing food by applying heat or other methods.;;;A method of preparing food for consumption, involving various chemical changes and interactions.;;;Processes that lead to the transformation of one set of chemical substances to another.;;;A metabolic process in which microorganisms break down sugars to produce acids, alcohol, and carbon dioxide.;;;A chemical reaction between amino acids and reducing sugars that occurs when food is cooked, leading to browning and the formation of new flavor compounds.;;;The process of preparing food by applying heat, which can be influenced by the presence of acids to enhance flavors and textures.;;;A process where substances are transformed into different substances through the breaking and forming of chemical bonds.;;;Methods used to prevent food spoilage and extend shelf life, including canning, freezing, drying, and fermentation.;;;The process of preserving food by anaerobic fermentation in brine or vinegar.;;;A process involving the transformation of substances into new compounds, often resulting in changes in properties and energy.;;;The scientific principles and processes involved in the preparation of food, affecting its taste, texture, and nutritional value.;;;Methods used to prevent food from spoiling and extend its shelf life.;;;The study of the chemical processes and transformations that occur during cooking.;;;The process by which two immiscible substances (such as oil and water) are combined to form a stable mixture, often with the help of an emulsifier.;;;The scientific study of the chemical processes and transformations that occur during the preparation of food.;;;The process of mixing two immiscible liquids to form a stable emulsion.;;;A stable mixture of two immiscible substances, one of which is dispersed throughout the other in very small droplets.;;;A chemical reaction between amino acids and reducing sugars that occurs when food is cooked, baked, or grilled, contributing to flavor and color.;;;A chemical reaction between amino acids and reducing sugars that usually occurs when food is cooked, baked, or grilled, leading to the formation of new compounds responsible for flavors and aromas.;;;Two immiscible liquids commonly used in the formation of an emulsion.;;;A process where two immiscible substances (such as oil and water) are combined to form a stable mixture, often used in cooking to create sauces and dressings.;;;A metabolic process in which microorganisms convert organic compounds into acids, gases, or alcohol.;;;A chemical reaction between amino acids and reducing sugars that occurs when food is cooked, leading to the browning of foods and the development of complex flavors.;;;A process in which two immiscible substances, such as oil and water, are combined to form a stable mixture through the use of an emulsifier.;;;The process of preparing food by applying heat, often involving various methods such as boiling, frying, or baking.;;;A chemical reaction between amino acids and reducing sugars that occurs when food is cooked, leading to the formation of new compounds responsible for flavors and aromas.;;;The process of preserving food by immersing it in a brine solution or vinegar to prevent spoilage and enhance flavor.

entity7.name: proteins
entity7.description: Large biomolecules or macromolecules consisting of one or more long chains of amino acid residues.
entity7.chunkid: The Chemistry of Cooking5;;;The Chemistry of Cooking21

entity8.name: sugars
entity8.description: A class of sweet, short-chain, soluble carbohydrates that are important in the biological processes of many organisms.;;;Simple carbohydrates that are the building blocks of more complex carbohydrates.
entity8.chunkid: The Chemistry of Cooking5;;;The Chemistry of Cooking24

entity9.name: heat
entity9.description: A form of energy transfer from one body to another due to a difference in temperature.

entity10.name: browning
entity10.description: The process by which food changes color, typically turning brown, as a result of chemical reactions involving amino acids and reducing sugars.

entity11.name: flavor compounds
entity11.description: Substances that contribute to the taste and aroma of food, often produced through various cooking processes.

entity13.name: roasted meats
entity13.description: Meats that have been prepared using a roasting method, which typically involves cooking in an oven or over an open flame to enhance flavor and texture.

entity14.name: grilled vegetables
entity14.description: Vegetables that have been cooked using a grilling method, which involves direct heat from below or all around, often resulting in charred marks and enhanced flavors.

entity15.name: baked goods
entity15.description: A wide range of food items prepared by baking, such as breads, pastries, cakes, and cookies, often characterized by their texture and flavor developed during the baking process.

entity21.name: sauces
entity21.description: Prepared liquid or semi-liquid mixtures that are served with dishes to add flavor or moisture.;;;Condiments or sauces typically used to add flavor to salads, vegetables, and other foods.

entity23.name: mayonnaise
entity23.description: A thick, creamy sauce made primarily from egg yolks, oil, and lemon juice or vinegar, often used as a condiment or ingredient in various dishes.

entity25.name: cooks
entity25.description: Individuals who prepare food for consumption, often in professional settings like restaurants or at home.;;;Professionals skilled in the preparation and cooking of food, often working in restaurants or culinary institutions.;;;Professional cooks who work in restaurants and other food service establishments, responsible for preparing meals and managing kitchen staff.;;;Professional cooks who prepare meals and manage kitchen staff.;;;Professionals who prepare and cook food in various settings such as restaurants, cafes, or private homes.
entity25.chunkid: The Chemistry of Cooking15;;;The Chemistry of Cooking29;;;The Chemistry of Cooking22;;;The Chemistry of Cooking11;;;The Chemistry of Cooking18

entity27.name: Acids
entity27.description: Substances that can donate a proton or form a bond with an electron pair, often found in foods and used to influence flavor, texture, and structure.;;;Substances that can donate a proton or accept an electron pair in reactions, often characterized by their sour taste and ability to react with metals.;;;Substances that can donate protons or hydrogen ions in a chemical reaction, playing various roles in food chemistry and preservation.;;;Substances that can donate a proton or form a bond with an electron pair, often used in food to enhance flavor and preserve.;;;Substances that can donate a proton or form a bond with an electron pair, often used in cooking to balance flavors.;;;A class of chemical compounds that can donate protons or accept electrons, often used in cooking to tenderize meat and balance flavors.
entity27.chunkid: The Chemistry of Cooking15;;;The Chemistry of Cooking24;;;The Chemistry of Cooking13;;;The Chemistry of Cooking16;;;The Chemistry of Cooking12;;;The Chemistry of Cooking30

entity29.name: flavor
entity29.description: Sensory attributes of food that can be affected by various factors including chemical reactions and temperature.;;;A characteristic of food that combines taste, smell, and other sensations experienced during consumption, often enhanced or modified by acids.
entity29.chunkid: The Chemistry of Cooking12;;;The Chemistry of Cooking20

entity30.name: texture
entity30.description: The feel or consistency of a substance, which can be altered in cooking through the use of acids to achieve desired mouthfeel and structure.

entity31.name: structure
entity31.description: The arrangement or composition of parts in food, which can be influenced by acids to create specific forms or consistencies during cooking.

entity33.name: lemon juice
entity33.description: A liquid extracted from lemons, used for its flavor and acidity in cooking and beverages.

entity34.name: fruit salad
entity34.description: A mixture of various fruits, often served as a dessert or side dish.

entity38.name: salts
entity38.description: Ionic compounds composed of cations and anions, commonly used to season food and regulate enzymatic reactions during cooking.;;;Ionic compounds composed of cations (positively charged ions) and anions (negatively charged ions), used for flavoring and food preservation.;;;A common mineral used in cooking to enhance flavor.;;;A common mineral composed primarily of sodium chloride, used to flavor and preserve food.
entity38.chunkid: The Chemistry of Cooking18;;;The Chemistry of Cooking16;;;The Chemistry of Cooking17;;;The Chemistry of Cooking30

entity42.name: Temperature control
entity42.description: The practice of managing the temperature during cooking to achieve desired outcomes, such as proper doneness or texture.;;;A method used in cooking to manage the heat applied to food, affecting its preparation and safety.
entity42.chunkid: The Chemistry of Cooking19;;;The Chemistry of Cooking30

entity46.name: temperature ranges
entity46.description: The range of temperatures at which certain processes or phenomena occur.

entity49.name: meat
entity49.description: Animal flesh that is eaten as food, typically from mammals and birds.

entity50.name: eggs
entity50.description: Reproductive bodies produced by female animals, often consumed as a food source.

entity51.name: temperature
entity51.description: A measure of the average kinetic energy of particles in a substance.

entity59.name: microorganisms
entity59.description: Small living entities that can only be seen with a microscope, including bacteria, fungi, and protozoa.

entity62.name: alcohol
entity62.description: An organic compound containing one or more hydroxyl groups attached to a carbon atom, commonly produced by the fermentation of sugars.

entity63.name: carbon dioxide
entity63.description: A colorless and odorless gas composed of one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms, often a byproduct of cellular respiration and fermentation.

entity65.name: Brine Solution
entity65.description: A concentrated solution of salt and water, often used in pickling to preserve food by inhibiting microbial growth.

entity66.name: Spoilage Microorganisms
entity66.description: Microscopic organisms that can cause food to spoil or decay, leading to a loss of quality and safety in the food product.

entity70.name: culinary arts
entity70.description: A discipline involving the practice, techniques, and skills used in cooking and food preparation, often taught as a profession.
